5. DISCUSSION 780 

5.1. Identification of a Lowstand Systems Tract 781 

The results found in the present study are consistent with the works of other 782 

researchers in the Irati Formation in the region (e.g., Araújo, 2001; Lavina, 1991; 783 

Menezes, 1994; Padula, 1968). Lithostratigraphic limits and fossil content are also 784 

very similar (Lavina et al., 1991; Matos et al., 2013; Soares, 2003). The sequence 785 

stratigraphy, on the other hand, has important points to be highlighted. 786 

The three sequences here recognized are similar to the fourth-order sequences 787 

of Araújo (2001), but there are some relevant differences. The sequence boundaries 788 

of IS2 and IS3 are traced at the base of the carbonate levels, which are considered 789 

as LSTs. As explained in section 4.3.2, the abrupt change in lithology registering a 790 

strong progradation of the shoreline, allied with the progradational-aggradational 791 

stacking pattern is here considered not likely to have been caused by a normal 792 

regression. A LST had already been suggested by Cassel, M.C. (personal 793 



38 
 

 

communication, 2016), while working on boreholes on the same region. In this sense, 794 

the sequences become more similar to the fourth-order sequences of Hachiro (1996). 795 

Recognition of lowstand systems tracts in carbonate ramps, especially 796 

homoclinal ramps, are relatively uncommon (Burchette and Wright, 1992). This is 797 

mainly due to their very low relief (less than 1°), which disfavors the formation of 798 

incised valleys and lowstand fans and aprons (Wright and Burchette, 1996). Even so, 799 

expected characteristics of LSTs in carbonate ramps are strongly progradational 800 

units and high-energy deposits of reworked material (Burchette and Wright, 1992; 801 

Wright and Burchette, 1996). 802 

MacNeil and Jones (2006) describe the reef complexes and associated deposits 803 

in a gently sloping, epicontinental ramp of Alexandra Formation, Late Devonian 804 

(Frasnian) of Western Canada. The fourth-order sequence of Reef Complex #2 saw 805 

an estimated sea-level drop of approximately 17 m, which moved the carbonate 806 

factory to the outer ramp. This created a high-producing and high-energy 807 

environment, as evidenced by intraclastic grainstones and rudstones, deposited over 808 

reefs of the previous HST. The two HST saw little carbonate deposition, and the HST 809 

of Sequence #2 is hardly differentiated from the TST on the outer ramp. 810 

Differentiation of forced regression from normal regression is due to many factors, 811 

including lack of deep to shallow water transitional deposits, and the distance 812 

covered by the regressive deposits (around 18 km), which is considered too great for 813 

a normal regression. This work shows that a fourth-order sea-level fall can generate 814 

a forced regression, even in a low-gradient epicontinental ramp. Also, that carbonate 815 

production can be enhanced during lowstand, generating high-energy reworked 816 

deposits, similar to the mid-ramp intraclastic grainstone facies of the IS2 and IS3. 817 

Tucker et al. (1993) applied sequence stratigraphy concepts to the Middle 818 

Triassic Muschelkalk carbonates of the Catalan Basin in eastern Spain. The authors 819 

recognize the uppermost Buntsandstein, the Middle Muschelkalk, and the Keuper 820 

units of that basin as LST from third-order sequences, characterized by hybrid 821 

sedimentation (marls) and evaporites, much alike the IS2. 822 

In the Middle Cretaceous carbonate ramp of northern Sinai, Bachmann and Kuss 823 

(1998) identify several third-order LST in the Upper Aptian to Cenomanian 824 

succession. In the carbonate-dominated “Unit B”, lowstands are characterized by 825 



39 
 

 

peritidal, brackish, and restricted facies with terrigenous influence overlying marine 826 

strata. Frequent emergence (subaerial exposure) horizons in some sections are 827 

interpreted as higher-frequency cycles operating in low accommodation space. 828 

Coexisting brackish and restricted conditions are also interpreted for the Irati 829 

Formation (Araújo, 2001) and, similarly, subaerial exposure is interpreted in the 830 

present work to be caused by low accommodation space. 831 

Van Steenwinkel (1990) describes a carbonate ramp setting at the northern edge 832 

of the Cornwall-Rhenish basin (Belgium), at the Devonian-Carboniferous transition 833 

(top-Strunian to base-Tournaisian). Offshore (outer ramp) sediments are abruptly 834 

overlain by shoreface, intertidal, and lagoon (inner ramp) facies. Erosion, pebble 835 

lags, and skeletal intraclasts (relicts) mark a third-order sea-level fall. These skeletal 836 

intraclasts are interpreted as the result of “more or less” in-situ organism production, 837 

which are continuously reworked because of the continuing relative sea-level fall. 838 

The reworked deposits described in this work are much akin the intraclastic 839 

pygocephalomorph-bearing grainstones of the IS3, and led to similar interpretations. 840 

Sea-level fall promoted carbonate production and redeposition.  841 

All of these characteristics are similar to the ones found in the LST of SI2 and 842 

SI3. Most cases are, however, considered third-order sequences, while the 843 

sequences “inside” the Irati Formation are usually considered to be of the fourth-844 

order scale (Araújo, 2001; Hachiro, 1996; Menezes, 1994). A lowstand systems tract 845 

in a carbonate ramp could be generated by enhanced carbonate production due to 846 

restriction of the basin during lowstand and movement of the carbonate factory to a 847 

more basinal and less prone to erosion position. This raises, however, a discussion 848 

regarding the hierarchy of these sequences. 849

5.3. Fossil occurrence control 905 

Recognition of a stratigraphic framework for the Irati Formation revealed strong 906 

facies and sequence control over fossil occurrence in the studied section. Physical 907 

factors had a major influence, especially oxygenation levels, storm wave bottom 908 

energy, and sediment supply. Unsurprisingly, different fossils had different responses 909 

to each set of physical conditions. It is of notice, however, that each of the most 910 

abundant fossils (paleonisciforms, pygocephalomorphs, and mesosaurids) is vastly 911 

dominant in specific systems tracts. 912 

5.3.1. Paleonisciform fish fossils – Early HST 913 

Mostly scales and teeth, paleonisciform fish fossils are found isolated or in thin 914 

concentrations (Figure 6), and are most common at the early HST of SI1 and SI2. 915 

The concentration of these fossils in these specific intervals might be explained by a 916 

sedimentation rate “balance”. Deposition on outer ramp environment during the TST 917 

is more punctuated, derived from major storm action in between hiatal periods. The 918 

fragile fish bones possibly did not resist to prolonged destructive processes on the 919 

water-sediment interface, such as dissolution, and possibly biogenic action. On the 920 

other hand, increasing sedimentation rate during progradation of the late HST 921 

drowned the fossils. 922 

Vertebrate accumulations in marine environments are much less studied than 923 

their invertebrate counterparts (Rogers & Kidwell, 2000). In addition, when compared 924 

to sequence stratigraphy, integrated models are absent even for shelly 925 

accumulations (Brett, 1995; Holz & Simões, 2005). So, predictions of vertebrate 926 

accumulations in submarine settings in relation to facies, bathymetry, and sequence 927 

stratigraphy are even more tentative (Rogers & Kidwell, 2000), although some 928 

progress has been made (e.g., Boessenecker et al., 2014; Matos, 2013; Peters et al., 929 

2009; Soares, 2003). 930

5.3.2. Pygocephalomorph grainstones – LST 942 

The vast majority of pygocephalomorph carapaces occur in grainstones with 943 

hummocky, and upper-flow plane-parallel stratification (Cgp facies). This facies 944 

contains the “Type C Accumulation” of Matos et al. (2013). These authors highlight 945 

how unusual it is for small and thin crustacean carapaces to occur alongside larger 946 

mesosaurid bones (up to 4 cm long ribs), even considering early diagenesis 947 

mineralization. Another appointed unusual aspect of this accumulation is that the 948 

mostly organic pygocephalomorph carapaces would deteriorate in a short period of 949 

time, an aspect which caused the authors to evoke mass mortality and simultaneous 950 

rapid burial as the process to allow fossilization. 951 

In fact, the pygocephalomorph fossils are usually in upper-flow plane-parallel 952 

bedding, an even higher-energy structure than the transitional hummocky cross-953 

stratification (Dumas and Arnott, 2006) in which the mesosaurids are more commonly 954 

found. This can be explained by the carapaces composing sand-sized intraclasts 955 

(sometimes up to granule size; Figure 9). The early mineralization and fossilization is 956 

explained by hardground or firmground formation due to low accommodation space 957 

on a carbonate inner to mid-ramp (Bosence and Wilson, 2003; Demicco and Hardie, 958 

1994; Jones, 2010; Pratt, 2010). This indicates these are reworked deposits from 959 

previously deposited, semiconsolidated sediments already containing 960 

pygocephalomorph fossils. Thus, this fossil concentration is a combination of a hiatal 961 

concentration (by firmground formation) and subsequent concentration through 962 

reworking caused by storm action (Brett, 1995; Holz and Simões, 2005; Kidwell and 963

Bosence, 1991), corroborating the multi-episodic and proximal tempestite 964 

interpretations of Matos et al. (2013). 965 

On a biostratinomic perspective, the firmground origin interpretation of the 966 

present work implies that the storm events were not necessarily a direct cause of 967 

death for all the pygocephalomorph individuals. A part of the assemblage might have 968 

died of natural causes. Matos et al. (2013) also observes that complete individuals 969 

never form dense accumulations. These authors interpret this feature as moments of 970 

low abundance of pygocephalomorphs due to stressing conditions (such as 971 

hypersalinity, as proposed by Piñeiro et al., 2012), or few occurrences of mass 972 

mortality events. Alternatively, this mode of occurrence might represent the normal, 973 

“day-to-day” rate of mortality, while the accumulations are the result of diagenetic and 974 

reworking events. 975 

On the other hand, storms are a known and common cause of animal death and 976 

fossil concentration (Brett and Seilacher, 1991; Rogers and Kidwell, 2007), and the 977 

preservation characteristics of pygocephalomorph occurrences not contained in 978 

intraclasts (type 1 preservation of Matos et al., 2013), usually found in shales are 979 

commonly attributed to burial due to distal sediment flows caused by storms (Brett et 980 

al., 2012; Brett and Seilacher, 1991). 981 

Therefore, the cause of death and accumulation of the pygocephalomorph 982 

carapaces are here considered to have a multiple origin. Mass mortality probably did 983 

occur episodically, but background bioclastic input might also be registered, and both 984 

were enhanced by firmground formation and storm reworking in the LST of the IS3. 985

6. CONCLUSIONS 1082 

Depositional and preservation dynamics in the Whitehill-Irati Sea, and 1083 

consequently the rock record of the Irati Formation are the result of a combination of 1084 

processes. The main physical factors operating in this environment were: (1) energy 1085 

of storm waves affecting bottom sediments (and also lifeforms), controlled by 1086 

bathymetry; (2) oxygenation levels at the sediment-water interface, controlled by 1087 

quality of water circulation (hindered by water stratification); and (3) rate of sediment 1088 

input, terrigenous or carbonate. All of these are in turn controlled by relative sea-level 1089 

change. A comprehension of the sequence stratigraphy of this sedimentary 1090 



49 
 

 

succession is thus essential for the comprehension of how these processes 1091 

interacted, and resulted in the record of physical conditions, and lifeform activity 1092 

found within these rocks. 1093 

Concluding remarks of this study are: 1094 

1. Three stratigraphic sequences could be recognized for the Irati Formation in 1095 

the studied area, termed IS1, IS2, and IS3, and are considered to be of 1096 

fourth-order hierarchy. The two overlying sequences, IS2 and IS3, present 1097 

lowstand systems tracts. 1098 

2. The third-order systems tracts related to the Irati Formation are not 1099 

consensus among authors. The findings of this study support the 1100 

interpretation of Raffaelli et al. (1996, apud Araújo, 2001) and Milani (1997). 1101 

3. The mesosaurid concentrations, along with pygocephalomorph crustaceans 1102 

fossil concentrations are restricted to the SI3. This allows correlation of 1103 

borehole data with the fossil-bearing outcrops in the Rio Grande do Sul state, 1104 

positioning them in the upper Assistência Member. This pattern resembles the 1105 

informal biostratigraphy Hachiro (1996). 1106 

4. Fossil concentrations are strongly controlled by facies and sequence 1107 

stratigraphy (accommodation space and sediment supply). The 1108 

paleonisciform fish fossils are the result of a sedimentation rate “balance”: not 1109 

too much and not too little. The mesosaurid and pygocephalomorph 1110 

accumulations are the result of combined factors: mass mortality and 1111 

background bioclastic input enhanced by hiatal and reworked concentrations. 1112 

Nature of hiatus is firmground formation for the pygocephalomorphs, and 1113 

sediment omission for the mesosaurids. 1114 

5. Sequence stratigraphy has proven an excellent tool for the identification and 1115 

interpretation of factors controlling sediment deposition, and consequently 1116
